titleproper.value:
Guide to the Papers of Joseph Dallet, Jr.
                    <num>ALBA.032</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Jodi Helman

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2012-03-28T16:24-0400</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: Joseph Dallet, Jr. (1907-1937) was a labor organizer and Communist Party activist. He volunteered with the Abraham Lincoln Brigade in the Spanish Civil War and was killed in action in October 1937. The bulk of the collection is correspondence from Dallet to his family during the 1920s and early 1930s, describing his political and labor-movement work. Also included are political materials and sympathy correspondence to the family after his death in Spain.

p.value:
Published citations should take the following form: 
                <lb/>
                <lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; 
                <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives 
                <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library 
                <lb/>70 Washington Square South 
                <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

<list>
                    <item>Dallet, Joseph, Jr., 
                        <title render="italic">Letters from Spain by Joe Dallet American Volunteer, To His Wife</title>. New York: Workers Library Publishers, 1938.</item>
                    <item>Nelson, Steve, James Barrett, and Rob Ruch, 
                        <title render="italic">Steve Nelson: American Radical</title> (Pittsburgh, PA: Pittsburgh University Press, 1981).</item>
                </list>

Series II: Subject Files, 1929-1946. Labor and political materials include leaflets, flyers and mayoral candidacy notices. There are also and obituary and memorial clippings, a memorial poem by Dallet's sister, Peg, a life insurance policy, and an article by Dallet in 
                <title render="italic">The American Teacher</title>.

corpname.value: Spain. Ejercito Popular de la Republica. MacKenzie-Papineau Battalion.
